description: From Latin periphrasis from Ancient Greek περίφρασις (períphrasis), from περιφράζομαι (periphrázomai, “I consider all sides of an issue”), from περί (perí, “around”) + φράζω (phrázō, “I show, point out”). See phrase.

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) The use of more words than are necessary to express the idea; a roundabout, or indirect, way of speaking; circumlocution.
examples: To describe all those on whom the fates of Troy hinged , by enigmatic periphrases

verbs.description: periphrase (third-person singular simple present periphrases, present participle periphrasing, simple past and past participle periphrased)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To express by periphrase or circumlocution.
